reviewText:
Documentary about a wagon train in the Mountain Meadow area of Utah. The party were killed by the settlers of a nearby town. All were shot except for a few children.

There have been several monuments to the fallen in this area and this film includes the controversy over the monuments and the events after the killings.

To me this was always a footnote in history. I have found limited information about the topic. Now I can see more of the story. This story is told in an even manner. There are still many living relatives of the slain party. There story is included.

In history, murder or war, religion has played a sad part. Those religions who commit the crime seek to cover up, alter, minimize or deny their culpability. Judaism, Isalm, and Catholicism has a chapter. On September 11th 1857, in Utah, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints wrote their chapter with the blood of the Fancher-Baker party as they travelled through from Arkansas to California. This well researched, moving documentary explains the massacre in Mountain Meadows and how 142 years later the decendents on both side struggle over the monument and how history of this event should be remembered. This is not a film set to portray The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in a negative light. This documentary is a matter-of-fact telling of how the descendants of both the victims, survivors, and perpetrators make peace.

If you want to find out the telling of the actual incident, then you need to see History Channel's "Investigating History: Mountain Massacre" DVD.

The problem is that the Mormon (LDS) church Prez. won't take responsibility or admit guilt for the massacre even though the murderers were all Mormons.  (You see this said by the families of the survivors in the DVD.  The LDS's lawyers are afraid to open the church up to lawsuits.

The real solution, of course, is for the descendants of the murderers to apologize to the descendants of the victims and survivors.

Then true healing can begin.

I've read, listened to lectures about, watched documentary after documentary and studied the Mountain Meadows Massacre from just about every source imaginable.  I've even suffering through the engaging but woefully inaccurate Hollywood movie, "September Dawn" (Bill McKeever and Aaron Shafovaloff's analysis of everything that's wrong with that film is excellent.

That's why I can say with some degree of authority that this documentary is the most thorough, thoughtful, and historically accurate short summary of the Massacre and it's fall out that I have found to date.

I would recommend this documentary to anyone who is interested in the Massacre whether it's an event that you're new to or long studied in.

I would also recommend this documentary to anyone who has ever wondered, "What happened AFTER the Massacre?" this documentary answers that question as well.

And as a note to fellow Mormon Studies Scholars I feel obligated to mention that this documentary contains what appears to be the only surviving record of the infamous Gordon B. Hinckley September 11, 1999 Dedication Speech at the new Mountain Meadows Massacre Memorial site in which he stated explicitly, "They [the Massacre Victims] did nothing wrong".  The inclusion of this rare and extraordinary speech - alone -  makes this documentary worth the price of admission!

OUTSTANDING documentary! The best detailed account of the horrors and aftermath of the Mountain Meadows Massacre. Very well researched and documented. Without admitting guilt or involvement, the Mormons have assisted the descendants of the tragedy with the building of memorials in addition to maintaining the site, which is a step in the right direction. I doubt the church will ever admit to any wrongdoing, in spite of the fact that the blood of the victims are all over their warped religious ideology and delusional leadership. While difficult and challenging, it is good to see that descendants from both sides have reached out to one another in forgiveness and apology. Perhaps the Mormon Church can learn from them and issue a formal apology and responsibility for their part in this horrible event? We'll see.......

this is a great documentary of how a historical tragedy perpetuated by an independent local & isolated community many years ago effects lives today. it's difficult to understand, impossible to forget, hard to forgive, & terribly natural for today's descendants on both sides to blame "higher powers", distant powerful leaders & organizations for the wrongs perpetuated on their ancestors by a local community. this film does not answer the questions which will never be answered, but helps us understand, & hopefully helps descendants to forgive & go on with their lives

Tells it like it is.  If you are LDS you should watch this but you probably will be afraid to.  Please don't be.  It tells of a horrible event in a fair and sensitive way and how ancestors on both sides are working together to bring about truth that the church has hidden and  much needed changes it has stood in the way of.
Tragic story that should be more widely known. Interesting production. Certainly worth the price

I would highly recommend this documentary.  It contains information about a very important part of American history that is little known. It also happened on Sept 11th, but in 1857.  Having just learned recently that my family was one of the leaders of the massacred wagon train, it made the film that much more insightful.
It looks at the massacre from both the victims and the perpetrators perspective.
We live close to the area It took place. That's why I was interested in it.

History lesson with ah twist...  Makes me angry when I consider the facts One of the worst cases of  Mass Premeditated Murder in the entire history of the United States. This film should be required viewing for 7th graders when they learn their state history.
The film maker did an outstanding job of story telling. The only problem as I see it,  the vast majority of folks who would undoubtably enjoy seeing the film will never get the chance, because of distribution problems  and piracy of copy written material.
Documentary film makers work so hard assembling the small Army of dedicated craftsmen that is needed to concoct a project  of  this sort   I for one appreciate  great story telling of American Crime History and this little film is a home run... Everyone I lend the DVD to is fascinated ... They also want to know why in the HELLo it was omitted from being taught in High School or Jr High.
I was surprised to see that it was a documentary. Maybe I didn't notice when I ordered. However, it was very informative. It's a part of our past IN the U.S. that should not be forgotten.
